definitions: feel or show deep sympathy and concern for someone experiencing hardship or suffering
examples: She always compassionates with families who have lost their homes
Good doctors compassionate with their patients during difficult diagnoses

definitions: give something to make up for loss, suffering, or injury that has occurred
give someone money in exchange for work done or to cover expenses
examples: The airline compensated passengers for the cancelled flight delays
Extra vacation days compensated for the weekend overtime work
The company compensates its employees fairly with competitive salaries
Freelancers should compensate for taxes in their hourly rates

definitions: collect information from different sources and arrange it in a book, report, or list
convert computer program source code into machine-readable instructions that can be executed
examples: She compiled all the research data into one comprehensive report
The editor compiled the best poems into an anthology
The programmer needs to compile the code before running it
This software compiles Java programs into executable files quickly

definitions: add to something in a way that improves it or makes it more complete
examples: The red wine perfectly complements the rich flavors of steak
Her skills in design complement his technical expertise well

definitions: make something more difficult or confusing by adding extra problems or details
examples: Don't complicate the issue by bringing up past arguments
The new regulations will complicate the approval process significantly

definitions: express praise, admiration, or approval about someone's appearance, achievements, or qualities
examples: He complimented her on the delicious meal she prepared
The teacher complimented the students for their hard work

definitions: collect and store plant material so it decays and becomes fertilizer for soil
examples: We compost all our kitchen scraps in the backyard bin
Many gardeners compost fallen leaves to enrich their soil naturally

definitions: understand the nature, meaning, or importance of something completely and clearly
examples: Young children cannot comprehend complex mathematical concepts easily
She finally comprehended the full impact of her decision

definitions: calculate a number or amount using mathematics or a computer system
examples: The accountant computed the total expenses for the fiscal year
Modern computers can compute millions of calculations per second

definitions: deceive someone into giving money or doing something through lies or tricks
examples: The scammer tried to con elderly people out of their savings
Don't let smooth talkers con you into bad investments

definitions: keep something secret or hidden from sight or knowledge of others
examples: She tried to conceal her disappointment with a forced smile
The thief concealed the stolen jewelry in a hidden compartment

definitions: admit that something is true or valid after first denying or resisting it
admit defeat in a contest or stop trying to win
examples: He finally conceded that his brother was right about the investment
The senator conceded the point during the heated debate
The candidate conceded the election after the final votes were counted
Our team had to concede defeat in the championship game

definitions: form an idea or concept of something in your mind through abstract thinking
examples: Artists often conceptualize their work before starting the actual creation
It's difficult to conceptualize infinity or other abstract mathematical ideas

definitions: agree with someone or have the same opinion about something
examples: The board members concurred with the CEO's strategic vision
Medical experts concur that regular exercise improves mental health

definitions: make something shorter or more concentrated by removing unnecessary parts
change from gas or vapor into liquid form through cooling
examples: Please condense your report into a two-page executive summary
The editor condensed the lengthy novel into a shorter version
Water vapor condenses on cold windows during winter mornings
The steam from the shower condensed on the bathroom mirror

definitions: accept or allow behavior that is wrong or offensive to continue
examples: The school does not condone bullying in any form
Parents who condone bad behavior often raise difficult children

definitions: mark off or block an area using traffic cones for safety or direction
examples: Workers coned off the construction area for public safety
Police coned the accident scene to redirect traffic flow

definitions: have discussions with someone in order to exchange opinions or get advice
grant or give an official title, degree, benefit, or right to someone
examples: The lawyers need to confer before proceeding with the case
Department heads confer weekly about ongoing projects and issues
The university will confer honorary degrees at the graduation ceremony
The new law confers additional rights on disabled workers

definitions: tell someone about a secret or private matter while trusting them not to repeat it
examples: She confided her deepest fears to her best friend
Employees rarely confide in managers about personal problems

definitions: arrange or set up computer hardware or software for a particular purpose or use
examples: The IT team will configure your new laptop with necessary software
You need to configure the router settings for internet access

definitions: keep someone or something within certain limits of space, scope, or time
examples: Please confine your remarks to the topic being discussed
The doctor confined the patient to bed rest for recovery

definitions: take or seize someone's property with authority, especially as a penalty
examples: Airport security confiscated the passenger's prohibited items
Teachers often confiscate phones that disrupt classroom learning

definitions: behave according to socially acceptable standards, rules, or laws
examples: All products must conform to safety regulations before sale
Teenagers often struggle between conforming and expressing individuality

definitions: cause someone to become confused or perplexed, especially by being unexpected
examples: The magician's tricks confounded even the skeptical audience members
Complex legal jargon often confounds people without law degrees

definitions: dance in a line with hands on the hips of the person in front
examples: Wedding guests formed a conga line around the reception hall
The crowd began to conga through the streets during carnival

definitions: gather together into a compact mass or cluster of different things
examples: Small tech companies often conglomerate to increase market power
Sediments conglomerate over millions of years to form rock

definitions: tell someone that you are pleased about their success, good fortune, or achievement
examples: Everyone congratulated the couple on their engagement announcement
The coach congratulated the team for winning the championship

definitions: come together in a group or crowd, especially for a common purpose
examples: Students congregate in the cafeteria during lunch breaks
Protesters congregated outside the government building peacefully

definitions: form an opinion or theory about something without having definite proof
examples: Scientists can only conjecture about life on distant planets
Historians conjecture that the ancient civilization collapsed from drought

definitions: give the different forms of a verb according to tense, person, and number
examples: Students must learn to conjugate irregular verbs in Spanish class
The app helps users conjugate French verbs correctly

definitions: make something appear unexpectedly or seemingly from nowhere as if by magic
make someone think of or remember something
examples: The magician conjured a rabbit from his empty hat
The chef conjured an amazing meal from simple ingredients
The old photograph conjured memories of childhood summers
Certain smells can conjure powerful emotions and memories

definitions: overcome and take control of a place or people by military force
examples: Alexander the Great conquered vast territories across three continents
She worked hard to conquer her fear of public speaking

definitions: force someone by law to join the armed forces for military service
examples: The government may conscript young men during times of war
Many countries no longer conscript citizens for mandatory military service

definitions: make or declare something sacred or dedicate formally to a religious purpose
examples: The bishop will consecrate the new church building next Sunday
Ancient peoples would consecrate ground before building temples

definitions: protect something from harm, loss, or waste, especially natural resources
examples: We must conserve water during the drought season
The museum works to conserve ancient artifacts for future generations

definitions: comfort someone at a time of grief, disappointment, or sadness
examples: Friends tried to console her after she lost her job
Parents console their children when they have bad dreams

definitions: combine several things into a single more effective or coherent whole
examples: The company plans to consolidate its three offices into one location
Students should consolidate their notes before the final exam

definitions: habitually associate or spend time with someone, typically with disapproval implied
examples: Parents worried when their son began consorting with troublemakers
The politician was criticized for consorting with known criminals

definitions: make secret plans jointly to commit an unlawful or harmful act
examples: The group conspired to overthrow the corrupt government officials
Employees who conspire to steal company secrets face serious charges

definitions: severely restrict the scope, extent, or activity of something or someone
examples: Budget cuts will constrain our ability to hire new staff
Don't let fear constrain you from pursuing your dreams

definitions: make a marriage or relationship complete by having sexual intercourse
complete a transaction or bring something to a successful conclusion
examples: The couple waited until their wedding night to consummate their marriage
Traditional customs dictate when newlyweds should consummate their union
The lawyers worked overtime to consummate the business deal
Years of negotiation were needed to consummate the merger

definitions: make something impure or unsuitable by contact with something unclean or harmful
examples: Industrial waste can contaminate rivers and harm wildlife
One sick worker could contaminate the entire food supply

definitions: think about something deeply and at length, often to make a decision
examples: She sat quietly contemplating her future career options
Philosophers contemplate the meaning of existence and reality

definitions: mold or shape something to fit the curves or outline of something else
examples: The dentist will contour the filling to match your tooth
Makeup artists contour faces to enhance natural bone structure

definitions: deny the truth of a statement by asserting the opposite
examples: The witness testimony contradicted the defendant's version of events
Children often contradict their parents just to assert independence

definitions: violate or go against a rule, law, or principle
examples: The new policy contravenes existing labor protection laws
Their actions contravene the terms of the signed agreement

definitions: come together or bring people together for a meeting or activity
examples: The board will convene next Monday to discuss the proposal
World leaders convene annually at the United Nations summit

definitions: come together from different directions and meet at a particular point
examples: Three major highways converge at the city center
Protesters began to converge on the parliament building

definitions: engage in conversation with another person about various topics
examples: The two professors conversed about philosophy over coffee
She enjoys conversing with people from different cultural backgrounds
